I blame the undeservedly revered Ronald Regan, the real life political counterpart of Gordon Gekko "greed is good" evangelist for changing the values and character of our culture for the worse and I think permanently.

Regan detested the economic power and education levels of the middle class and their unions whom he thought to be too liberal, and createdt policies to reduce their size, wealth and political influence. He also began a political and propaganda war on the poor through lies and demonetization (Welfare Queens) and program cuts. He turned the middle class whites against the poor and further perfected Nixon's Southern strategy by announcing his presidential run in Philadelphia Mississippi, a KKK hot spot during the civil rights battles and the site of the murder of three young civil rights workers. His message to white working class was clear which over the years metamorphosized into the current Tea Party.

We are now seeing the fruits of his policies over the span of a third of a century in the enormous transfer of wealth to the upper classes via tax policy, the decimation of the middle class, the increasingly inferior status of our education system and the increasing unaffordable higher education.

Crafty politicians like Bill Clinton actually piggy backed on Reganism by rescinding Glass Steagall and bank deregulation, outsourcing via free trade, and telecommunication monopolies. His policies caused us pain we didn't need him to feel

What you sow, you reap!

I couldn't agree more with your comments on the the flow of money to athletics. Yes, in Connecticut we do have winning teams in both men's and women's basketball, but the drain on resources to pay the head coaches of both these teams is appalling when you hear of the cuts in other areas to our state university system. Consider also the low graduation rates of the men's team. As a taxpayer I'm tired of subsidizes what is in reality the National Basketball Association's "farm team". Jim Calhoun, the men's head coach, is the highest paid public employee in the state of CT. His annual salary is over $2 million. Geno Auriemma, women's head coach is paid "only" about $1.3 million. If both their salaries were cut by half, they would continue to be wealthy individuals, though no less overpaid, and the savings could sustain quite a few tenured professors in science and engineering with adequate research funding to do something more meaningful and beneficial to the country as a whole.

Today my state university cut dozens of majors, without building a case for why it needed to happen and without the support of faculty. Why is this happening? Because the Board of Regents, controlled by Republican ideals, wants cuts, cuts, cuts. Our state funding has plummeted over the past five years, and the cuts are like throwing red meat to the lions. We have no idea how much money these cuts will save, but it doesn't matter. This is all political theater. Meanwhile, millions of dollars flow from academics to our money-losing athletic department. Professors, vilified in the press, will be out of work and the classes we still need taught in those majors will go to adjuncts. Exactly what Republicans want and believe in.

This is yet more evidence of what Dr. Krugman is speaking to--public universities are being undermined by budget cutting mania in state governments at the expense of education quality. Our students pay more and more tuition to attend public universities with lesser and lesser educational value, but hey, at least there's sports to watch. We used to take pride in our public education here in the U.S., and now it's just another extravagance to cut. And I agree that there is much to gain for the 1% in keeping it that way.

The assualt on education is not surprising for a party that is faith-based rather than fact-based, both in religious and secular matters. The last thing Republicans want are constituents who are critical thinkers. They want constituents who function in a world of easy answers, a world where short-term benefits do not have long-term consequences.

Like many, I too would like a world with unlimited amounts of fossil fuels that do not have any environmental impact, where the more resources we use the more are created. I would like a world where chronic poverty does not put children at any competitive disadvantage. I would like a world where every business decision is made with the best interests of the larger society at heart.

Unfortunately, I'm a product of higher education. I was indoctrinated by faculty who required me to look for evidence to back up my conclusions and to not reflexively believe that every seemingly good idea or promise, no matter how well-intentioned, can or should come true. I learned that, as much as I may want it, the fact-based world won't bend to my wishes. While my gut is as susceptible as ever to the easy cures promoted in infomercials and candidate websites, thanks to college my head keeps bringing up nagging questions that I can't easily dismiss. Given what the Republican candidates want us to buy, it's no wonder that the thought of a better educated populace gives them the jitters.

I would never have gone to college if it had not been for the GI Bill.  And afterwards, I was able to further my education at UC, Berkeley thanks in large part to the fact that tuition was free in the early 1950s.  I am sure that the country also profited by the contributions I was able to make in my chosen field.

Since the death of William F. Buckley, the Republicans have simultaneously lost their intellectual core and allowed the formerly fringe elements of the party to completely take it over. Cynical calculations made by party leaders in the 70s made this inevitable when they began courting religious extremists, while the John Bircher types have been patiently waiting in the wings for decades.
The truly amazing thing about the GOP is that they are still around at all. After the Cheney/Rove/Bush regime fully exposed the GOP as a party that uses its proudly ignorant base to further the power of American aristocracy, they should have gone the way of the Whigs. The fact that they remain viable is a testament to the weakness of the Democrats and the appalling state of media. Much of this apparent Democratic weakness is do to the fact that both parties serve the same masters, and they need each other, in order to have an enemy for motivating the true believers, or to have someone to blame when they cannot fulfill their promises. If the Democrats had not sold the soul of the party (thank Clinton et al) in a never-ending arms race for money, and if they still governed as a truly, unapologetically modern liberal party, these freakishly conservative Republicans would have little or no impact on national politics.
America needs a healthy conservative and a healthy liberal political party, and it needs to be able to have constructive public discourse. Sadly, it has none of these.

Roger, I'm sure you learned a great deal and made the most of your opportunities. I'm a big fan of state schools as well (received two degrees from one, taught at one). And I'm sure you compete quite well when matching your acquired skill sets against those from more prestigious institutions. I've been pretty lucky in that regard myself. What I didn't get, though, at my less respected school, was the chance to befriend and be friends with future members of Fortune 500 corporate boards. That can happen at the best state schools, but it happens more rarely there than at the most expensive private schools. Perhaps your experience was different.
I done know how long ago you went to college,  but the days when public universities provided a good, cheap alternative are long gone.

I'm loathe to say this, but I actually agree with what Romney said except for the last sentence (not forgiving debt).  From what I've read and my own personal experience, I think you get just as good an education, if not better, at state schools than at private schools.  It all depends on the willingness of the student to put in the time to understand the concepts behind the material, to do the homework and to do the brute force memorization.  I went to state schools for both undergrad. and grad. school and have competed just fine than people from far more prestigious schools.  I think one of the problems we have in this country is that people go way too far into debt just to send their kids to the "best" schools when they could be going to much cheaper and just as good state schools.  But, given this,  I totally agree with Dr. K. that we need to provide much more funding for state colleges so that they don't have to raise their tuition and fees as much.

The Party of Plutocracy has been attacking public education for decades by promoting a variety of voucher schemes, charter schools,privatization boondoggles, and home schooling scams like Rick Santorums $30,000 charge to Pennsylvania taxpayers for a "cyber-school". The only thing accomplished by most such schemes has been, first, to siphon public money out of public schools and into private pockets, and second, to reduce the power of unionized public employees. These have nothing to do with improving education, although they are generally marketed as providing "choice".  When the extremists who now control the Republican party in Wisconsin gained control of both the governorship and legislature, the first thing they did was to outlaw collective bargaining for public employees, including teachers by inserting a rider in a so-called "budget-balancing" bill, though no mention had been made of such action in their 2010 campaign.  Expect the same kind of assault on teachers and public education with any Republican president and congress..
